content.question: Which of the following best helps explain why an atom of <math alttext="R b" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Rb</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gas more easily loses an electron in a chemical reaction than an atom of <math alttext="L i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Li</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gas?

choices.label: <math alttext="R b" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Rb</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> has a higher electronegativity than <math alttext="L i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Li</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> has.

The <math alttext="R b" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Rb</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atom has a greater number of valence electrons than the <math alttext="L i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Li</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atom has.

The nucleus of the <math alttext="R b" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Rb</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atom has a greater number of protons and neutrons than the nucleus of the <math alttext="L i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Li</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atom has.

In the <math alttext="R b" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Rb</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atom the valence electron is farther from its nucleus than the valence electron of <math alttext="L i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Li</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is from its nucleus.

content.answer: In the <math alttext="R b" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Rb</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atom the valence electron is farther from its nucleus than the valence electron of <math alttext="L i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Li</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is from its nucleus.
